newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU joins forces on satellite communications.
newsitem.headline: EU joins forces on satellite communications.

text.p: European Union governments and industry leaders have joined forces to try to boost Europe's satellite communications industry in the face of tough competition from the United States.
The two sides came together on Thursday at a conference in Paris that highlighted the need for the EU to develop a more coordinated strategy for the fast-growing sector.

"If Europe does not react in a coordinated way, there is a high risk that it will be cut out of the most promising markets," the European Commission, which hosted the meeting, said in a statement on Friday.

The Commission -- which united representatives of the 15 EU governments and companies such as French aerospace group Aerospatiale, British Telecom and Luxembourg satellite operator Societe Europeenne des Satellites (SES) -- has been worried about growing U.S. dominance in commercial satellite communications.
It notes in a background paper that the U.S. industry has already launched proposals for global satellite communications systems worth $50 billion.
For example, Teledesic, a joint venture involving Microsoft Corp chairman Bill Gates, plans to launch hundreds of satellites to offer voice and data connections across the globe.
The U.S. has also licensed several satellite groups that are poised to offer mobile telephone and data-transmission services, or "personal communications", by the end of the decade.
They include Globalstar, led by Qualcomm Inc and Loral Corp; Iridium, led by Motorola Inc ; and Odyssey, with TRW Inc and Canada's Teleglobe Inc.
The U.S. has already won an advantage for its systems during international negotiations on frequencies for satellite communications, the Commission said.
It also expressed concern about the U.S.'s threat to keep satellite communications out of the World Trade Organisation talks on telecoms liberalisation and about recent proposals.

The Commission noted that European groups have begun to express interest in the sector, citing SES, France's Alcatel, Italy's Alenia Spazio and satellite organisation Eutelsat. But it said the industry is in a precarious position.

"Despite the tremendous efforts over the last 30 years, the European satellite equipment and service industry is not well placed to achieve the position in the commercial space sector needed to support the ambitions of the European Union to remain a major player in this sector," the Commission said.

The industry and government officials who met in Paris agreed that EU authorities needed to cooperate more in regulating the sector and to speak with one voice in international bodies such as the World Radiocommunication Conference, the Commission said.
But they did not endorse the idea of setting up a single European regulator -- at least in the short term, it added.

The Commission has had trouble convincing EU governments to set up a single system for selecting and licensing satellite communications operators. EU ministers agreed a watered-down plan last month, however, that sets up more coordination.
Participants at Paris also agreed that EU research programmes should give priority to satellite communications and that the European industry needed restructuring, the Commission said.
